Award.AbstractNarration: Pelesko<br/>0807546<br/><br/> In this project, the investigator, his colleagues, and a<br/>team of undergraduate researchers study electrocapillary surfaces<br/>and electro-elastocapillary systems. Electrocapillary surfaces<br/>are capillary surfaces, i.e., surfaces which minimize surface<br/>energy subjected to a volume constraint, that are placed in an<br/>electric field. Electro-elastocapillary systems are<br/>electrocapillary surfaces that are additionally constrained to<br/>reside on a flexible elastic body. Mathematical models of these<br/>systems are developed via a variational principle. The resulting<br/>systems of coupled nonlinear partial differential equations are<br/>studied using tools from perturbation theory, nonlinear dynamics,<br/>and numerical analysis. In addition, experiments are carried out<br/>in the investigator's laboratory and the mathematical theory is<br/>compared with experimental data. <br/><br/> Microelectromechanical systems (MEMS) operate at a scale<br/>where forces common to everyday experience, such as gravity and<br/>inertia, hold no sway. Rather, in the microworld, behavior is<br/>dominated by less familiar forces such as surface tension and the<br/>electrostatic force. Inspired and informed by recent advances in<br/>MEMS technology, this project develops the mathematical theory of<br/>systems dominated by the unique balance of capillary,<br/>electrostatic, and elastic forces. The development and analysis<br/>of this mathematical theory allows MEMS researchers to improve<br/>and optimize the design of MEMS devices. In turn, improved MEMS<br/>devices can be used in areas ranging from automotive safety to<br/>biomedical engineering. This project also focuses on outreach to<br/>mathematics faculty and students from local high schools. As<br/>part of this project, the investigator strengthens existing ties<br/>with several local high schools and help develop novel lab-based<br/>exercises to be integrated into the high school mathematics<br/>curriculum. <br/>

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES
